You really don\'t get the point of the game, do you?

Of course the cool stuff requires time to train. You don\'t expect that on the first day in the army, you get to command an aircraft-carrier, derp around in a submarine and launch nukes at shit, do you? Flying a Titan might take more that a year of training, but it is basically a mobile space station, where other ships can dock in, and have backup and jump clones in.

You don\'t have to pay 15 pounds per month, if you can make, and spare 400 million Isk per month, you can buy it in-game.

Alliances can\'t betray you, because you can\'t be in an alliance. You can be in a corporation, what can be in an alliance, but the alliance has no power over the corporations, so no power over you.

And of course battleships aren\'t superior, why would they be? Battleships are fleet ships, and are weaker without the support of a fleet. If you want a good ship, settle with a battlecruiser, and max out your skills for it, and put good equipment on it. A maxed out battlecruiser can take a lesser battleship out. And don\'t forget that battleships have huge cannons, and therefore have a hard time hitting small targets, such as frigates, so a bunch of frigates can also take a battleship out, if they work together.

And regarding making Isk, you can make enough fairly easily. If you go mining, invest some money in it. Don\'t expect to make millions per day in a mining frigate, but in vest some money for a small mining barge, with strip miners, and you can easily get a million per load.

And don\'t forget, the higher the risk, the higher the reward. If you go out in lowsec, you might run into some rats, and if you manage to kill them, they might have some nice loot on them. If you manage to take out a player, you get some of his equipment that he had, and the items in his cargo.

Also, every type of turret has it\'s strengths and weaknesses, for example, hybrids and railguns are strong in PvE, while if you\'re doing fleet battles, they are next to useless. And for example, the strength of an energy turret is that you don\'t need ammo, but it takes it\'s energy from the capacitor. There is no real best weapon. If you train the required skills, and use it in the effective range, you can do good damage with every type of turret.

Please don\'t run around and share your experiences with others when they are factually inaccurate.

Do missions while you train the most important combat and fitting skills, you should be at level 4 missions when the skills are trained up, then you\'re ready for PvP. Join a null-sec corporation that is in an alliance with sovereignty, do anomalies in their owned systems for ISK, and if you joined a good alliance, they will have a ship replacement fund (repaying you for your losses in alliance operations) and keeping your wallet filled will be easy. I don\'t remember my wallet going below 500m ISK this month and I play only ~5 hours weekly with minimal PvE. (doing anomalies I earn around 60m ISK per hour)

Joing EVE-uni would be pretty good - they teach their members the ways of PvP and general game mechanics etc.

Join RvB if you want some frigate-destroyer-cruiser cheap pew pew in high-sec.

Alternatively you could do trading (time-consuming), manufacturing or exploration. You could also be everything, but to do everything properly, it would take a while (read: years) to train.

One thing to note is, EVE is not about doing everything, it\'s about specialization.

It\'s not THAT hard to learn to play, I did when I was what, 14 years old.

BTW, flying a frigate with semi-decent agility, you cannot die to a gate-camp in low-sec unless you\'re trying to. Null-sec is a totally different story though, with interdiction bubbles all over the place, preventing you from warping away.

You\'re right, skills take a while to train, but EVE is not a grindfest (thankfully).

You know, paying for gametime with ISK is pretty stupid. It would make EVE a second, very very poor job:

60m per hour (my current earnings), needing 500m to pay for 1 month of gametime, 1 month = 15 GBP

It would take 8.3 (repeating) hours for me to earn 1 month of gametime, which equals to 1.8 GBP per hour...

CONCLUSION: You\'re better off getting a job in real life and spending that money on game time or ISK.

You should research corps before joining them. Some corps scam their newbies, some corps pay their members, etc.

In EVE, very little skills are 'time wasted' (some of them are: railgun specialization, amarr and caldari drone specialization...). Guess what can take down a battleship gang? A bigger battleship gang. You\'re gonna need that skill sooner than later.

A battleship can shut down a frigate with a single cycle of a heavy neut, and a cruiser with 2-3 cycles.

You never, EVER undock in something you cannot afford to lose. And if you can, you better have it insured, because no one ship lasts forever. You also never go to low-sec with a mining barge, that\'s asking for trouble.

Autocannons are fine (short range big damage), blasters are fine as well (shorter range biggest damage), railguns are fine (you should see a sniper Naga fleet in action), pulse lasers are OP (with scorch ammo - insane DPS projection out to ~80km).

All weapons besides smartbombs, bombs, drones and FoF missiles require lock. Missiles also always hit, although they are rather ineffective. Projectile turrets (autocannons, artillery), bombs and missiles don\'t require capacitor.

I\'ve been playing for 4 years with a 1.5 year break in between (so 2.5yrs technically) and I\'m doing fine. I went into null-sec after getting bored with missioning and am now happily residing in Pure Blind in the Goonswarm and FA systems, doing alliance and corp ops over the weekends, earing some ISK and camping EC-P8R during the week.
